column14: they may use a gas bomb like the Rodenator to destroy the warren and kill or relocate the rabbits. Also works well to kill rats and moles. column60: victims have told her about opening a separate bank account when they get a raise and asking their employer to divert that money to a secret account. Victims have also asked their boss not to give them a raise. But there is no national research to show how widespread these tactics are or whether the violence increases as the victim gains more economic independence. Several studies offer anecdotal evidence that abuse may increase as victims try to improve their economic status or employment prospects. For instance
column61: a June 2016 study by Partners for a Competitive Workforce finds that intimidation and intimate partner violence can discourage enrollment and participation in education and training programs. Similarly
column62: a National Resource Center on Domestic Violence study found that domestic violence typically escalates when a survivor enrolls in education or training.  However

column69: the philanthropic arm of Allstate Insurance Company
column70: with bringing awareness to financial abuse 10 years ago with its Purple Purse program
column71: aimed at helping financial abuse and domestic violence victims. A cornerstone of the program is an online financial curriculum
column73: which was developed specifically to help financial abuse victims leave their abusers
column75: and restore their credit rating. To date
column78: which is available in English and Spanish. In 2014

column85: not just put a Band-Aid on the problem.” The course encourages victims to take small steps towards leaving their abuser: Postmus and Ray-Jones both agree more needs to be done to study the long-terms effects of financial abuse. For now

column1: adeptis 160091282013 "2017-04-28 18:30:09 GMT" https://adeptis.tumblr.com/post/160091282013/a-biology-teacher-just-destroyed-every-excuse-for "badscienceshenanigans:  sentinelviktorcullen:  prettyaveragewhiteshark:  This is AMAZING. The teacher’s rebuttal:  I just commented this on a transphobic post that was all like
column2: “In a sexual species
column3: females have two X chromosomes and males have an X and a Y
column4: I’m not a bigot it’s just science.” I’m a science teacher so I responded with this. First of all
column6: you can have females be XX and males be X (insects)
column7: you can have females be ZW and males be ZZ (birds)
column8: you can have females be females because they developed in a warm environment and males be males because they developed in a cool environment (reptiles)
column9: you can have females be females because they lost a penis sword fighting contest (some flatworms)
column10: you can have males be males because they were born female
column11: but changed sexes because the only male in their group died (parrotfish and clownfish)
column12: you can have males look and act like females because they are trying to get close enough to actual females to mate with them (cuttlefish
column15: or you can be one of thousands of sexes (slime mold
column17: did you mean humans? Oh ok then. You can be male because you were born female
column18: but you have 5-alphareductase deficiency and so you grew a penis at age 12. You can be female because you have an X and a Y chromosome but you are insensitive to androgens
column19: and so you have a female body. You can be female because you have an X and a Y chromosome but your Y is missing the SRY gene
column20: and so you have a female body. You can be male because you have two X chromosomes
column21: but one of your X’s HAS an SRY gene
column22: and so you have a male body. You can be male because you have two X chromosomes- but also a Y. You can be female because you have only one X chromosome at all. And you can be male because you have two X chromosomes
column23: but your heart and brain are male. And vice - effing - versa. Don’t use science to justify your bigotry. The world is way too weird for that shit.   Addressing this to the TERF that assaulted me.  as a biologist I love that humans think there are 2 sexes but mold just said “fuck the police I’ll be genetically compatible with whatever 698
column24: 307 sexual variants I want” " False link

column1: adeptis 158667191721 "2017-03-21 15:00:12 GMT" https://adeptis.tumblr.com/post/158667191721/boycotts-almost-surely-will-never-work "justsomeantifas:  Veganism is a boycott that’s likely doomed for failure. Far from “saving lives
column2: ” as most animal rights groups falsely claim
column3: the conventional focus on consumer action may very well be ensuring our movement’s irrelevance. What’s the alternative? To recognize that the boycott is just one among many tactics. To push the boundaries of political imagination to find more inspiring models of action: protest
column4: storytelling
column5: norm formation (such as the Liberation Pledge)
column8: direct rescue and liberation. To create agents of change
column9: to connect them into empowered communities and networks
column10: and to inspire those networks to take powerful political – not consumer
column11: but political – action for animals. At root
column12: the intuition is quite simple. The boycott is simply “not doing something.” But what this movement needs – what the animals need – is not a movement of “do nothings” but “do somethings.” So let’s go out and do something for animals. " False link

column1: adeptis 158523019673 "2017-03-17 21:00:14 GMT" https://adeptis.tumblr.com/post/158523019673/everyone-loves-bernie-sanders-except-it-seems "berniesrevolution: room-where-it-happens: philsandifer:  berniesrevolution:  If you look at the numbers
column2: Bernie Sanders is the most popular politician in America - and it’s not even close. Yet bizarrely
column3: the Democratic party - out of power across the country and increasingly irrelevant - still refuses to embrace him and his message. It’s increasingly clear they do so at their own peril. A new Fox News poll out this week shows Sanders has a +28 net favorability rating among the US population
column4: dwarfing all other elected politicians on both ends of the political spectrum. And he’s even more popular among the vaunted “independents
column5: ” where he is at a mind boggling +41. This poll is not just an aberration. Look at this Huffington Post chart that has tracked Sanders’s favorability rating over time
column6: ever since he gained national prominence in 2015 when he started running for the Democratic nomination. The more people got to know him
column7: they more they liked him - the exact opposite of what his critics said would happen when he was running against Clinton. One would think with numbers like that
column8: Democratic politicians would be falling all over themselves to be associated with Sanders
column9: especially considering the party as a whole is more unpopular than the Republicans and even Donald Trump right now. Yet instead of embracing his message
column10: the establishment wing of the party continues to resist him at almost every turn
column11: and they seem insistent that they don’t have to change their ways to gain back the support of huge swaths of the country. Politico ran a story just this week featuring Democratic officials fretting over the fact that Sanders supporters may upend their efforts to retake governorships in Southern states by insisting those candidates adopt Sanders’ populist policies - seemingly oblivious to the fact that Sanders plays well in some of those states too. Sanders’s effect on Trump voters can be seen in a gripping town hall this week that MSNBC’s Chris Hayes hosted with him in West Virginia - often referred to as “Trump Country” - where the crowd ended up giving him a rousing ovation after he talked about healthcare being a right of all people and that we are the only industrialized nation in the world who doesn’t provide health care as a right to all its people. (Continue Reading)  Well
column13: the fact that he joined the party
column14: ran a destabilizing primary campaign that hurt their eventual candidate because he was unwilling to actually accede to basic norms like shutting the fuck up and endorsing the winner
column15: and then immediately left the party again probably didn’t make him many friends in the party establishment. I don’t say any of this as a knock against Sanders
column16: whose politics I continue to like more than Democrats and considerably less than actual socialism
column17: but you really don’t have to scratch your head for answers on why the party isn’t embracing someone whose dealings with them basically consist of shouting “I’m going to throw you under the bus the moment it’s convenient for me” over and over again.  Which has been my response this whole time. Shocker
column18: Democratic Party doesn’t like a guy who isn’t a Democrat. Of course my additional response is to then note that if you don’t like it actually join the party. Now is probably a great time to do so if you want to steer it more left/liberal. Like
column19: party membership costs practically nothing in the US: just have to check a box on voter registration form. Full transformation requires more involvement obviously
column20: but that at least allows you to vote in the primaries (tis why honestly I favor closed primaries). Granted
column21: I honestly still don’t buy the idea he’d have beaten Trump.Trump and Bernie both share populist economic appeal
column22: but Trump offered ethnic nationalism too and we all know how that goes in the US. And Bernie gets the glow of “what could have been” too. But I think the fact he couldn’t even win the primary elections and did well mostly in caucuses (most inaccessible form of primaries) should be a big sign maybe he didn’t have the appeal his supporters thought.  A Parties whole purpose is to win elections. This is something we must remember when we analyze these responses. Now
column23: if the most popular politician in America with a voter database the party is trying to get ahold of is willing to work with you
column24: you might want to find a way to make the party endearing to him and his supporters. The issue is by alienating Bernie Sanders
column25: the Democratic Party is alienating his supporters as well
column26: supporters that will be needed to to win future elections.If a parties whole purpose is to get people elected

column1: adeptis 151448612504 "2016-10-07 00:42:24 GMT" https://adeptis.tumblr.com/post/151448612504/transgender-women-are-facing-a-devastating-medical "vaspider:  gaywrites:   Bamby Salcedo describes the past month of her life in one word: “devastation.” It was late August when the activist and community organizer first learned about the ongoing injectable estrogen shortage in the United States
column2: which has been gradually impacting the lives of transgender women and transfeminine people like herself for over a year now. As the nation’s supply dries up
column3: trans people who rely on injectable estrogen are panicking. “Members of the community are not finding out” about the shortage
column4: Salcedo told me. “I don’t think many service providers even know about it. I still have not received notice from a doctor.” In fact
column5: if it weren’t for an acquaintance who works at the clinic she goes to
column7: who founded the Los Angeles-based TransLatin@ Coalition in 2009 to advocate for the needs of trans Latinx immigrants in the U.S.
column8: might still be in the dark about the status of her medication
column9: which she described as “life-saving.” Synthetic estrogen plays a crucial role for trans women and transfeminine people who choose to undergo hormone replacement therapy as a means of medically transitioning. Yet the growing disappearance of its injectable form from the pharmaceutical market has gone largely unnoticed beyond the circles of those affected. Salcedo said that she has “not seen any” media coverage of the shortage
column10: despite the subject’s constant presence on her various social media feeds. That’s not surprising. In the eight weeks since Out magazine’s website broke the news of the “Injectable Estrogen Shortage That’s Leaving Trans Women in Crisis
column11: ” very few outlets have picked up the story. This silence
column13: must be broken. “They would not deny a person who is diabetic their medication
column14: right?” she asked. “Access to hormones saves lives. Not having this medication puts us in danger.”  This is critically important. Hormone access can literally be a matter of life and death; we have to keep talking about this.   Wait
